steps.title: Information Gathering / Recon
steps.caption: Please include any valuable pieces of information found; and the source of said information

items.title: Credentials or keys leaked on Github, Pastebin, etc.
Usernames, emails, passwords, and other information leaked as part of past breaches.
Internal subdomains, known software, etc.
Check for the ability to perform a zone transfer on the in-scope IP addresses

steps.title: Scanning
steps.caption: Please include your full nmap scan output + banner information in a single file. Similarly, include all other tooling outputs.

items.title: Fully scan the range of in-scope targets (all 65,535 TCP and UDP ports).
Ensure that hosts are still scanned, even if they’re not responsive to a ping sweep.
Enumerate and document all in-scope services and version numbers.
Document services that communicate insecurely (e.g. telnet, http).
Document any services with misconfigured DNS records allowing for subdomain takeovers.
Review results and leverage any available services to obtain more information around the targets and/or users. Examples: RPC, SMB, SMTP, SNMP, etc.

steps.title: Exploitation
steps.caption: Include any screenshots as proof of successful exploitation. For unsuccessful attacks, please document the commands/tools executed.

items.title: Check for lack of auth/default creds to any available services. e.g. auth portals, anonymous FTP, SSH, RDP, mail relays, etc.
Check for any auth bypasses on any available services.
Cross reference software version numbers against known vulnerable versions/exploits (exploit db, CVEs, etc; often facilitated by the use of nessus/nikto/openvas/etc).
Configure and attempt to exploit any known vulnerabilities (existing scripts with custom shellcode, metasploit modules, etc).
Check for the presence of sensitive information that’s publicly available on any service (e.g. documents available via anonymous FTP).
Test any available webservers for server-side vulnerabilities including Auth bypasses
Test any available webservers for server-side vulnerabilities including Default credentials
Test any available webservers for server-side vulnerabilities including Known exploits based on running vulnerable software
Test any available webservers for server-side vulnerabilities including SQL Injection (SQLi)
Test any available webservers for server-side vulnerabilities including Remote Code Execution (RCE)
Test any available webservers for server-side vulnerabilities including XML Entity Injection (XXE)
Test any available webservers for server-side vulnerabilities including Server Side Request Forgery (SSRF)
Test any available webservers for server-side vulnerabilities including Local/Arbitrary File Inclusion (LFI/AFI)
Test any available webservers for server-side vulnerabilities including Hidden directories or pages with sensitive information
Run a basic web application scanner over the app, and report any valid issues. (nikto, burp, zap, et al)
Attempt moderate, informed/educated brute-forcing on available services - based on information gathered earlier in the assessment.
